model_parameters.name: is_data_valid
model_parameters.description: This function is called with the randomly selected data before the model is fitted to it: is_data_valid(X, y). If its return value is False the current randomly chosen sub-sample is skipped.

model_parameters.name: is_model_valid
model_parameters.description: This function is called with the estimated model and the randomly selected data: is_model_valid(model, X, y). If its return value is False the current randomly chosen sub-sample is skipped. Rejecting samples with this function is computationally costlier than with is_data_valid. is_model_valid should therefore only be used if the estimated model is needed for making the rejection decision..

model_parameters.name: loss
model_parameters.description: If loss is a callable, then it should be a function that takes two arrays as inputs, the true and predicted value and returns a 1-D array with the i-th value of the array corresponding to the loss on X[i].

model_parameters.name: alpha
model_parameters.description: Value added to the diagonal of the kernel matrix during fitting. Larger values correspond to increased noise level in the observations. This can also prevent a potential numerical issue during fitting, by ensuring that the calculated values form a positive definite matrix. If an array is passed, it must have the same number of entries as the data used for fitting and is used as datapoint-dependent noise level. Note that this is equivalent to adding a WhiteKernel with c=alpha. Allowing to specify the noise level directly as a parameter is mainly for convenience and for consistency with Ridge.

model_parameters.name: kernel_optimizer
model_parameters.kind_of_value: {'fmin_l_bfgs_b', externally defined optimizer passed as a callable }
model_parameters.description: Optimizer to optimize the kernel parameters.

model_parameters.name: n_restarts_optimizer
model_parameters.description: The number of restarts of the optimizer for finding the kernel's parameters which maximize the log-marginal likelihood. The first run of the optimizer is performed from the kernel's initial parameters, the remaining ones (if any) from thetas sampled log-uniform randomly from the space of allowed theta-values.

model_parameters.name: normalize_y
model_parameters.description: Whether the target values y are normalized, i.e., the mean of the observed target values become zero. This parameter should be set to True if the target values' mean is expected to differ considerable from zero. When enabled, the normalization effectively modifies the GP's prior based on the data, which contradicts the likelihood principle.

model_parameters.name: copy_X_train
model_parameters.description: If True, a persistent copy of the training data is stored in the object. Otherwise, just a reference to the training data is stored, which might cause predictions to change if the data is modified externally.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. model_parameters.name: perplexity
model_parameters.description: The perplexity is related to the number of nearest neighbors that is used in other manifold learning algorithms. Larger datasets usually require a larger perplexity. Consider selecting a value between 5 and 50. The choice is not extremely critical since t-SNE is quite insensitive to this parameter.

model_parameters.name: early_exaggeration
model_parameters.description: Controls how tight natural clusters in the original space are in the embedded space and how much space will be between them. For larger values, the space between natural clusters will be larger in the embedded space. Again, the choice of this parameter is not very critical. If the cost function increases during initial optimization, the early exaggeration factor or the learning rate might be too high.

model_parameters.name: learning_rate
model_parameters.description: The learning rate for t-SNE is usually in the range [10.0, 1000.0]. If the learning rate is too high, the data may look like a \u2018ball\u2019 with any point approximately equidistant from its nearest neighbours. If the learning rate is too low, most points may look compressed in a dense cloud with few outliers. If the cost function gets stuck in a bad local minimum increasing the learning rate may help.

model_parameters.name: min_grad_norm
model_parameters.description: If the gradient norm is below this threshold, the optimization will be stopped.

model_parameters.name: distance_metric
model_parameters.kind_of_value: {'cityblock', 'cosine', 'euclidean', 'l1', 'l2', 'manhattan', 'braycurtis', 'canberra', 'chebyshev', 'correlation', 'dice', 'hamming', 'jaccard', 'kulsinski', 'mahalanobis', 'matching', 'minkowski', 'rogerstanimoto', 'russellrao', 'seuclidean', 'sokalmichener', 'sokalsneath', 'sqeuclidean', 'yule', a callable that should take two arrays as input and return one value indicating the distance between them}
model_parameters.description: The metric to use when calculating distance between instances in a feature array.

This method is not very sensitive to changes in this parameter in the range of 0.2 - 0.8. Angle less than 0.2 has quickly increasing computation time and angle greater 0.8 has quickly increasing error.

model_parameters.description: When pre-computing distances it is more numerically accurate to center the data first. If copy_x is True, then the original data is not modified. If False, the original data is modified, and put back before the function returns, but small numerical differences may be introduced by subtracting and then adding the data mean.

model_parameters.name: algorithm
model_parameters.description: K-means algorithm to use.

optimisation_parameters.name: num_initialization
optimisation_parameters.description: Number of time the k-means algorithm will be run with different centroid seeds.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_iterations
optimisation_parameters.description: Maximum number of iterations of the k-means algorithm for a single run.

optimisation_parameters.name: precompute_distances
optimisation_parameters.description: Precompute distances (faster but takes more memory). \u2018auto\u2019 : do not precompute distances if n_samples * n_clusters > 12 million. This corresponds to about 100MB overhead per job using double precision.

optimisation_parameters.name: jobs
optimisation_parameters.description: The number of jobs to use for the computation. If -1 all CPUs are used.

model_parameters.name: num_clusters
model_parameters.description: The number of clusters to form as well as the number of centroids to generate.

model_parameters.name: initialization_method
model_parameters.description: Method for initialization.

model_parameters.name: batch_size
model_parameters.description: Size of the mini batches.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: Verbosity mode.

model_parameters.name: compute_labels
model_parameters.description: Compute label assignment and inertia for the complete dataset once the minibatch optimization has converged in fit.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. If int, random_state is the seed used by the random number generator; If RandomState instance, random_state is the random number generator; If None, the random number generator is the RandomState instance used by np.random.

model_parameters.name: tolerance
model_parameters.description: Control early stopping based on the relative center changes as measured by a smoothed, variance-normalized of the mean center squared position changes. This early stopping heuristics is closer to the one used for the batch variant of the algorithms but induces a slight computational and memory overhead over the inertia heuristic.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_iterations
optimisation_parameters.description: Maximum number of iterations over the complete dataset before stopping independently of any early stopping criterion heuristics.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_no_improvement
optimisation_parameters.description: Control early stopping based on the consecutive number of mini batches that does not yield an improvement on the smoothed inertia.

optimisation_parameters.name: initialization_size
optimisation_parameters.description: Number of samples to randomly sample for speeding up the initialization (sometimes at the expense of accuracy).

optimisation_parameters.name: num_initialization
optimisation_parameters.description: Number of random initializations that are tried.

optimisation_parameters.name: reassignment_ratio
optimisation_parameters.description: Control the fraction of the maximum number of counts for a center to be reassigned. A higher value means that low count centers are more easily reassigned, which means that the model will take longer to converge, but should converge in a better clustering.

model_parameters.name: damping
model_parameters.description: Damping factor is the extent to which the current value is maintained relative to incoming values (weighted 1 - damping). This in order to avoid numerical oscillations when updating these values (messages).

model_parameters.name: copy
model_parameters.description: Make a copy of input data.

model_parameters.name: preference
model_parameters.description: Preferences for each point - points with larger values of preferences are more likely to be chosen as exemplars. The number of exemplars, ie of clusters, is influenced by the input preferences value. If the preferences are not passed as arguments, they will be set to the median of the input similarities.

model_parameters.name: affinity
model_parameters.description: Which affinity to use.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: Whether to be verbose.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_iterations
optimisation_parameters.description: Maximum number of iterations over the complete dataset before stopping independently of any early stopping criterion heuristics.

optimisation_parameters.name: convergence_iteration
optimisation_parameters.description: Number of iterations with no change in the number of estimated clusters that stops the convergence.

model_parameters.name: bandwidth
model_parameters.description: Bandwidth used in the RBF kernel.

model_parameters.name: seeds
model_parameters.description: Seeds used to initialize kernels.

model_parameters.name: bin_seeding
model_parameters.description: If true, initial kernel locations are not locations of all points, but rather the location of the discretized version of points, where points are binned onto a grid whose coarseness corresponds to the bandwidth. Setting this option to True will speed up the algorithm because fewer seeds will be initialized.

model_parameters.name: min_bin_freq
model_parameters.description: To speed up the algorithm, accept only those bins with at least min_bin_freq points as seeds.

model_parameters.name: cluster_all
model_parameters.description: If true, then all points are clustered, even those orphans that are not within any kernel. Orphans are assigned to the nearest kernel. If false, then orphans are given cluster label -1.

optimisation_parameters.name: jobs
optimisation_parameters.description: The number of jobs to use for the computation. If -1 all CPUs are used.

model_parameters.name: num_clusters
model_parameters.description: The dimension of the projection subspace.

model_parameters.name: eigen_solver

model_parameters.name: kernel_coefficient

model_parameters.name: affinity
model_parameters.description: Which affinity to use.

model_parameters.name: num_neighbours
model_parameters.description: Number of neighbors to use when constructing the affinity matrix using the nearest neighbors method.

model_parameters.name: eigen_tol
model_parameters.description: Stopping criterion for eigendecomposition of the Laplacian matrix.

model_parameters.name: assign_labels
model_parameters.description: The strategy to use to assign labels in the embedding space. There are two ways to assign labels after the laplacian embedding. k-means can be applied and is a popular choice. But it can also be sensitive to initialization. Discretization is another approach which is less sensitive to random initialization.

model_parameters.name: kernel_degree
model_parameters.description: Degree of the polynomial kernel.

model_parameters.name: zero_coefficient

model_parameters.description: Connectivity matrix. Defines for each sample the neighboring samples following a given structure of the data. This can be a connectivity matrix itself or a callable that transforms the data into a connectivity matrix.

model_parameters.name: compute_full_tree
model_parameters.description: Stop early the construction of the tree at num_clusters. This is useful to decrease computation time if the number of clusters is not small compared to the number of samples. This option is useful only when specifying a connectivity matrix. Note also that when varying the number of clusters and using caching, it may be advantageous to compute the full tree.

model_parameters.name: linkage_criterion
model_parameters.description: Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion.

model_parameters.name: pooling_function
model_parameters.description: This combines the values of agglomerated features into a single value, and should accept an array of shape [M, N] and the keyword argument axis=1, and reduce it to an array of size [M].

model_parameters.description: The radius of the subcluster obtained by merging a new sample and the closest subcluster should be lesser than the threshold. Otherwise a new subcluster is started. Setting this value to be very low promotes splitting and vice-versa.

model_parameters.description: Maximum number of CF subclusters in each node. If a new samples enters such that the number of subclusters exceed the branching_factor then that node is split into two nodes with the subclusters redistributed in each. The parent subcluster of that node is removed and two new subclusters are added as parents of the 2 split nodes.

model_parameters.name: initialization_method
model_parameters.description: Method used to initialize the procedure.

model_parameters.name: solver
model_parameters.description: Numerical solver to use.

model_parameters.name: tolerance
model_parameters.description: Tolerance of the stopping condition.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. If int, random_state is the seed used by the random number generator; If RandomState instance, random_state is the random number generator; If None, the random number generator is the RandomState instance used by np.random.

model_parameters.name: regularization_multiplier
model_parameters.description: Constant that multiplies the regularization terms. Set it to zero to have no regularization.

model_parameters.name: l1_ratio
model_parameters.description: The ElasticNet mixing parameter, with 0 <= l1_ratio <= 1. For l1_ratio = 0 the penalty is an elementwise L2 penalty (aka Frobenius Norm). For l1_ratio = 1 it is an elementwise L1 penalty. For 0 < l1_ratio < 1, the penalty is a combination of L1 and L2.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: Whether to be verbose.

model_parameters.name: shuffle
model_parameters.description: If true, randomize the order of coordinates in the CD solver.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_iterations
optimisation_parameters.description: Maximum number of iterations during fit.

model_parameters.name: num_components
model_parameters.description: Number of topics.

model_parameters.name: doc_topic_prior
model_parameters.description: Prior of document topic distribution theta. If the value is None, defaults to 1 / n_components. In the literature, this is called alpha.

model_parameters.name: topic_word_prior
model_parameters.description: Prior of topic word distribution beta. If the value is None, defaults to 1 / n_components. In the literature, this is called eta.

model_parameters.name: learning_method
model_parameters.description: Method used to update _component. Only used in fit method. In general, if the data size is large, the online update will be much faster than the batch update.

model_parameters.name: learning_decay
model_parameters.description: It is a parameter that control learning rate in the online learning method. The value should be set between (0.5, 1.0] to guarantee asymptotic convergence. When the value is 0.0 and batch_size is n_samples, the update method is same as batch learning. In the literature, this is called kappa.

model_parameters.name: learning_offset
model_parameters.description: A (positive) parameter that downweights early iterations in online learning. It should be greater than 1.0. In the literature, this is called tau_0.

model_parameters.name: batch_size
model_parameters.description: Number of documents to use in each EM iteration. Only used in online learning.

model_parameters.name: evaluate_every
model_parameters.description: How often to evaluate perplexity. Only used in fit method. set it to 0 or negative number to not evalute perplexity in training at all. Evaluating perplexity can help you check convergence in training process, but it will also increase total training time. Evaluating perplexity in every iteration might increase training time up to two-fold.

model_parameters.name: total_samples
model_parameters.description: Total number of documents. Only used in the partial_fit method.

model_parameters.name: perplexity_tolerance
model_parameters.description: Perplexity tolerance in batch learning.

model_parameters.name: mean_change_tolerance
model_parameters.description: Stopping tolerance for updating document topic distribution in E-step.

model_parameters.name: max_doc_update_iteration
model_parameters.description: Max number of iterations for updating document topic distribution in the E-step.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: Controls the verbosity level.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. If int, random_state is the seed used by the random number generator; If RandomState instance, random_state is the random number generator; If None, the random number generator is the RandomState instance used by np.random.

optimisation_parameters.name: max_iterations
optimisation_parameters.description: Maximum number of iterations during fit.

optimisation_parameters.name: jobs
optimisation_parameters.description: The number of jobs to use in the E-step. If -1, all CPUs are used. If -1 all CPUs are used.

model_parameters.name: store_precision
model_parameters.description: Specifies if the estimated precision is stored.

model_parameters.name: assume_centered
model_parameters.description: If True, the support of robust location and covariance estimates is computed, and a covariance estimate is recomputed from it, without centering the data. Useful to work with data whose mean is significantly equal to zero but is not exactly zero. If False, the robust location and covariance are directly computed with the FastMCD algorithm without additional treatment.

model_parameters.name: support_fraction
model_parameters.description: The proportion of points to be included in the support of the raw MCD estimate. If None, the minimum value of support_fraction will be used within the algorithm: [n_sample + n_features + 1] / 2.

model_parameters.name: contamination
model_parameters.description: The amount of contamination of the data set, i.e. the proportion of outliers in the data set.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. If int, random_state is the seed used by the random number generator; If RandomState instance, random_state is the random number generator; If None, the random number generator is the RandomState instance used by np.random.

model_parameters.name: num_estimators
model_parameters.description: The number of base estimators in the ensemble.

model_parameters.name: max_samples
model_parameters.description: The number of samples to draw from X to train each base estimator.

model_parameters.name: contamination
model_parameters.description: The amount of contamination of the data set, i.e. the proportion of outliers in the data set.

model_parameters.name: max_features
model_parameters.description: The number of features to draw from X to train each base estimator.

model_parameters.name: bootstrap
model_parameters.description: If True, individual trees are fit on random subsets of the training data sampled with replacement. If False, sampling without replacement is performed.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: The seed of the pseudo random number generator to use when shuffling the data. If int, random_state is the seed used by the random number generator; If RandomState instance, random_state is the random number generator; If None, the random number generator is the RandomState instance used by np.random.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: Controls the verbosity of the tree building process.

optimisation_parameters.name: jobs
optimisation_parameters.description: The number of jobs to use for the computation. If -1 all CPUs are used.

model_parameters.name: num_neighbours
model_parameters.description: Number of neighbors to use by default for kneighbors queries.

model_parameters.name: algorithm
model_parameters.description: The algorithm to be used by the NearestNeighbors module to compute pointwise distances and find nearest neighbors.

model_parameters.name: leaf_size
model_parameters.description: Leaf size passed to BallTree or KDTree. This can affect the speed of the construction and query, as well as the memory required to store the tree. The optimal value depends on the nature of the problem.

model_parameters.name: distance_metric
model_parameters.kind_of_value: {'cityblock', 'cosine', 'euclidean', 'l1', 'l2', 'manhattan', 'braycurtis', 'canberra', 'chebyshev', 'correlation', 'dice', 'hamming', 'jaccard', 'kulsinski', 'mahalanobis', 'matching', 'minkowski', 'rogerstanimoto', 'russellrao', 'seuclidean', 'sokalmichener', 'sokalsneath', 'sqeuclidean', 'yule', a callable that should take two arrays as input and return one value indicating the distance between them}
model_parameters.description: The metric to use when calculating distance between instances in a feature array.

model_parameters.name: minkowski_parameter
model_parameters.description: Parameter for the Minkowski metric. When minkowski_parameter = 1, this is equivalent to using manhattan_distance (l1), and euclidean_distance (l2) for minkowski_parameter = 2. For arbitrary minkowski_parameter, minkowski_distance (l_p) is used.

model_parameters.name: metric_parameters
model_parameters.description: Additional keyword arguments for the metric function.

model_parameters.name: contamination
model_parameters.description: The amount of contamination of the data set, i.e. the proportion of outliers in the data set.

optimisation_parameters.name: jobs
optimisation_parameters.description: The number of jobs to use for the computation. If -1 all CPUs are used.

model_parameters.name: bandwidth
model_parameters.description: The bandwidth of the kernel.

model_parameters.name: algorithm
model_parameters.description: The tree algorithm to use.

model_parameters.name: kernel
model_parameters.description: The kernel to use.

model_parameters.name: distance_metric
model_parameters.kind_of_value: {'cityblock', 'cosine', 'euclidean', 'l1', 'l2', 'manhattan', 'braycurtis', 'canberra', 'chebyshev', 'correlation', 'dice', 'hamming', 'jaccard', 'kulsinski', 'mahalanobis', 'matching', 'minkowski', 'rogerstanimoto', 'russellrao', 'seuclidean', 'sokalmichener', 'sokalsneath', 'sqeuclidean', 'yule', a callable that should take two arrays as input and return one value indicating the distance between them}
model_parameters.description: The distance metric to use.

model_parameters.name: absolute_tolerance
model_parameters.description: The desired absolute tolerance of the result. A larger tolerance will generally lead to faster execution. Default is 0.

model_parameters.name: relative_tolerance
model_parameters.description: The desired relative tolerance of the result. A larger tolerance will generally lead to faster execution.

model_parameters.name: breadth_first
model_parameters.description: If true (default), use a breadth-first approach to the problem. Otherwise use a depth-first approach.

model_parameters.name: leaf_size
model_parameters.description: Leaf size passed to BallTree or KDTree. This can affect the speed of the construction and query, as well as the memory required to store the tree. The optimal value depends on the nature of the problem.

model_parameters.name: metric_parameters
model_parameters.description: Additional keyword arguments for the metric function.

model_parameters.name: num_components
model_parameters.description: Number of binary hidden units.

model_parameters.name: learning_rate
model_parameters.description: The learning rate for weight updates.

model_parameters.name: batch_size
model_parameters.description: Number of examples per minibatch.

model_parameters.name: verbose
model_parameters.description: he verbosity level. The default, zero, means silent mode.

model_parameters.name: random_state
model_parameters.description: A random number generator instance to define the state of the random permutations generator. If an integer is given, it fixes the seed. Defaults to the global numpy random number generator.

optimisation_parameters.name: num_iter
optimisation_parameters.description: Number of iterations/sweeps over the training dataset to perform during training.
